Problem:
Consider the analysis of the function \( z(t) = \int_0^t e^{sA}dsB \), where \( A \) and \( B \) are constant matrices. The system dynamics are investigated in relation to the Henstock-Kurzweil integral of the operator exponential, and its effect when applied as a transformation on a vector \( x_0 \).

If an intervention using a new function \( w(t) = \int_0^t e^{sC}dsD \) (where \( C \) and \( D \) are constant matrices) is applied at time \( t_1 \), does the final state \( x(T) \) for \( T > t_1 \) depend solely on the properties of \( A \) and not on \( B \), \( C \), or \( D \)?
Explanation: The introduction of the intervention \( w(t) \) adds another layer of complexity, integrating influences from matrices \( C \) and \( D \). This makes the final state \( x(T) \) a product not only of the original matrix \( A \) but also significantly influenced by \( B \), \( C \), and \( D \). Thus, the endpoint is a result of an interwoven effect of these matrices.

causal_map_integration: The final state x(T) depends on the integral function z(t) which is influenced by matrices A and B, and also on the integral function w(t) which is influenced by matrices C and D. For T > t1, if w(t) is applied at t1, x(T) will be affected by both z(t) and w(t), meaning it depends on A, B, C, and D.
